TopicTitle: mechjeb, ascent guidance inclination, and contracts.

Articles.Content:
I had a heck of a time today trying to Gert the right inclination for a satellite contract today. I can't recall the exact Longitude of Ascending Node, but I think it was 348Ã‚Â° and the inclination was 160.1Ã‚Â°.

Setting mj to 160Ã‚Â° was wrong, turns out -160Ã‚Â° was correct. Studying the impact of the Longitude of Asending Node reveals that mj seems to assume its 0Ã‚Â°.

So I'm looking for confirmation of this, and guidance on how to translate inclination from a given Longitude of Ascending Node to mechjebs assumed LoAN.

Edited January 23, 2015 by tg626

I've heard that Mechjeb uses 180>-180, whereas KSP generally uses a 360 degree compass for inclination.

I'm not sure about orientation, or how this interprets, but if I had to guess, I would say that the negative figures are south.

Also, this is third hand, and I have no references or proof of correctness.. sooo pretty much disregard this post
From the post I am not sure you grasp the definition of the Longitude of Ascending Node.

My grasp is tenuous. If fact further thought last night as I fell asleep lead me to realize 300some degrees can't be right as that's nearly all the way around to 0 again and it appeared that my fight was a mirror of what it was supposed to be.

Ok, got it. The reason that 160 degrees was the wrong setting was because I was launching when the DESCENDING node was directly above KSC. Had I been launching when the ASCENDING node of my target orbit was above KSC, then 160 degrees would have been the correct setting.

Since I was launching when the DESCENDING node was above KSC, I needed to set MechJebs "Inclination" to -160 degrees.

(duh)

BTW, the stated orbital parameters were:
